article.title: Citation Indexes
article.author: Weinstock, M.
article.text: Citation indexing is a relatively new method of organizing the contents of a collection of documents in a way that overcomes many of the shortcomings of the more traditional indexing methods. The primary advantage of citation indexing is that it identifies relationships between documents that are often overlooked in a subject index. An important secondary advantage is that the compilation of citation indexes is especially well suited to the use of man-machine indexing methods that do not require indexers who are subject specialists. Furthermore, citations, which are bibliographic descriptions of documents, are not vulnerable to scientific and technological obsolescence as are the terms used in subject indexes.
